Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the significance of the lower mass shootings death rate in the United States compared to several European countries.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a single study conducted by the Crime Prevention Research Center (CPRC).
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that comparing the death rates of mass shootings between countries is an accurate measure of the seriousness of gun violence.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the lower mass shootings death rate in the United States, such as differences in reporting methods or definitions of mass shootings.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by using inappropriate statistical methods to obscure the reality of mass shootings being rare in most countries.
Contradict fact: The claim may contradict the fact that the United States is the most consistent site of mass shootings among the countries analyzed in the study.
Understate: The claim may understate the potential impact of mass shootings by focusing only on public incidents and excluding other forms of gun violence like armed robberies or domestic incidents.
